snippet.textOriginal: Such a load of complete nonsense and lies. Advertising teaching? Where on earth do teachers get work in N.Ireland as there are no jobs. The secondary schools I have taught in our certainly not like the schools portrayed in this ad. Live in the real world. I have had books thrown at me , balls bounced off my head and threatened by pupils'. The work load is incredible and you end up marking over the holidays. Just feel this ad is totally unrealistic and I would never encourage anyone to go to train to be a teacher. In some schools you are never encouraged by senior management and when you sub you are v much treated as a second class citizen. This ad is totally unrealistic. If some of the teachers in this ad where to teach in the schools I have taught in they wouldn't last 5 mins. Disgusted.

snippet.textOriginal: oh dear. if only teaching was just like this video, however it is full of negativity, endless unreachable targets, constant criticism (even for outstanding teachers) and a never ending workload. no matter what, you never feel good enough. However, now a tutor, life is great and i get all the joy out of teaching without the crap and it is amazing how because my time is spent focusing on the lessons and how the children respond emotionally instead of putting them under stress, they make AMAZING progress. I am never going back! It saddens me to say this, as i love to teach, but the government have destroyed our wonderful schools, not just for teachers, but for innocent children. So don't teach, find another way and live your life happy. it breaks my heart to give that advice but you matter more than what the government will do to you. Trust me.

snippet.textOriginal:
<Long comment & being British I'll apologise for that>
#teachersmake 

It's a cringeworthy cliche to people who haven't walked a mile in the teacher's/ headteacher's shoes but it is I believe absolutely the case that cash never was an issue but it's being made into one now.  But why not? Cash is something that everyone has had some experience of like 'football', 'terror' and 'immigration'.

Are you 'great'?  How do you know?
Will Ofsted line up the great ones and put 'great' gold stickers on their sweaters?
Maybe parents will lobby SLT when their once disengaged son suddenly shows interest in maths again because of one teacher's quest for greatness?
What small behavioural modifications might emerge over time in teachers?
What crazy things might people find themselves doing in a couple of years that will seem perfectly justifiable looking back? 

Extremes...
"When does my son get that teacher with the Porsche?"
"Hey can I borrow your 'great' planning? "
"Sir, don't you want to be great?"
"We only employ 'great' teachers here."
"I"d like to see your budget Head Teacher." 
"What's the ratio of 'great teachers' to children in this school?"
"Your next target is to improve that ratio."
"How? We can't afford it?"
"You can't afford not to it's in the framework."

If you're ever in doubt about the driving force for a teacher doing what they do I'd urge anyone, who was able, to go support their school as a Governor or other role that would give just a hint of what it takes to do the 'job'.

How about some simple thanks, respect, recognition, less political meddling and time to invest in people's ongoing development?  Maybe in the future the divisive promise of increased potential cash earnings will cease to be the recommended way to market what is arguably one of the toughest vocations a person could choose to undertake?

I've never written a comment with 13 question marks in it before.

snippet.textOriginal: I thought there was such a thing as The Advertising Standards Authority. This crock of lying bullshit surely contravenes every one of their guidelines. As a comprehensive school Maths teacher, I ran that gruesome, threadbare gauntlet for decades, and bear the mental scars. The very fact that they are having to advertise should itself ring warning bells. How many adverts do you see encouraging you to train as a solicitor or accountant for instance? If you are a masochist with an independent income, or simply insane, then by all means be my guest. Otherwise, avoid it like the plague.

The very fact that they are having to advertise should itself ring warning bells. How many adverts do you see encouraging you to train as a solicitor or accountant for instance? If you are a masochist with an independent income, or simply insane, then by all means be my guest. Otherwise, avoid it like the plague.

snippet.textOriginal: Actually, the saying is 'this will make your jaw drop.' This just sums up the whole problem. Nowadays people just don't know things. When I when to school I was taught mental arithmetic, spelling, and English grammar. We had dictation, where the teacher read out passages from a famous novel and we had to copy it down longhand as he spoke. We were marked in this for neatness, punctuation and spelling. We were taught how to read through the lines and find any hidden meanings. We were taught critical thinking and how to analyse propaganda and loads more much needed stuff.None of this is taught any more and I very much doubt whether modern teachers are in fact capable of teaching at all, other than helping children pass a pre-set test. This is not really teaching.

snippet.textOriginal: This is a shameful video that doesn't address the heart of the issue. Teachers do what they do because they want to teach and make a difference.  All the red tape and data pushing and progress monitoring quashes creativity and prevents purposeful relationships to develop in the classroom.  A child's worth is not on whether they make 3 levels of progress,  and I resent a system that makes me think of a child as a means to a pay increase. Before anyone thinks I'm just thinking of teachers I'm also very concerned about the increase in stress and depression in children today.  Being under so much pressure from every single subject at school to evidence progress is just inhumane.  We are not preparing these children for life,  but stopping them from developing emotionally as well as intellectually.   I hope that the government will realise soon that they are putting teachers,  students AND parents through a guinea pig system that hinders and does not transform society on the ground level.  Don't get me wrong,  I love love my job but the problem will not be sorted with these pitiful policies and proposals. This survey needs to take into account the 4000 teachers leaving the profession each month.  Perhaps the findings might have been different if the 10s of thousands of teachers were included.  Just a thought...

This response is bitterly disappointing and  total paper shuffling. It has utterly wasted 44,000 teachers precious time who took part in the DfE survey. Maybe you mislaid what was requested, so here's another look at what will make a difference ... 
Reform accountability so it is based on trust. Introduce fundamental change on requirements relating to marking, planning, data, meetings and observations. 
Allow time for curriculum and SEN reform.  Reform the teacher pay system. 
Require schools to adopt a binding work-life balance policy.
Set targets to reduce workload and introduce limits.
Increase teacher numbers to improve education.

snippet.textOriginal: So much of this makes sense, the issues regarding levels and the meaning of level 3, undue pace, labelling.  BUT....whilst this makes sense, the Secondary system is all about getting pupils to a grade by May / June in the year of their year 11, or 'fail' an Ofsted etc.  However in schools around the UK, there are leadership teams that judge a teacher's pay based on levels,  whole class progress etc....with an Ofsted inspectorate that suffer similar myopic vision.  Laudable aims, rationalised and supported, but it will not be easy, will be tinkered with for political aims (it is about time Education is NOT subject to the whims of political ideologies and becomes cross party) and takes time.....will schools really be allowed such?  Then the question needs to be asked about what is in the KS4 PoS.......why is it important that ALL pupils know certain facts (e.g. know 18 formulae in Science by rote, rather than be able to apply in a variety of contexts or why some of the more popular science ideas are removed).  I wish I could speak freely to the likes of ministers, Head of Ofsted, Mr Oates, the exam boards in a single room and force them to speak to each other, join up all thoughts and listen to real world teachers.  It will never happen, and thousands of pupils each year will be taught in a system that is not fit for purpose.......or maybe, just maybe this time it will be different from the numerous politically motivated changes...............but I will not put my money on it.  I reiterate, the most valuable change that can be made to the education of millions of children in the UK is to remove the political influences.

So Y2 teachers are still being asked to churn out at least 30% of their children at Level 3 and Y6 teachers 40% at Level 5.

snippet.textOriginal: I am pleased with the shift in more learning focused assessment that this presentation advocates and as a secondary school teacher I think that a lot of us have been aware of the false picture of progress created by a threshold driven model of assessment. So the move towards greater emphasis on conceptual learning and the acknowledgement of the unevenness of learning which levels do not allow for is far more enlightened and meaningful. The big problem, which in many ways is the elephant is the room, is enabling state school teachers to have the time to do justice to this approach. In the context of an overburdened workforce the quality and quantity of feedback which this approach demands will be difficult to achieve. I am interested to know how other countries which take such an approach resource their assessment systems to allow them to be successful. Last year I had 420 books to mark and trying to get books marked even once a term was a real struggle. I am sure that I am not alone in this regard.

snippet.textOriginal: Discussing the complexities of learning without acknowledging the coercion behind that learning is rather like discussing borders without acknowledging the wars that created those borders. Parents are coerced into paying for government education whether they choose schools, or home schooling; children are coerced into attending schools. Whether a child wishes to be in school learning a particular curriculum according to a particular methodology is the most crucial factor in whether they succeed and flourish, or fail and decline and yet _key concepts_ are discussed instead of the fundamental immorality of forced education.

snippet.textOriginal: I've just finished my first week of teaching practice as part of my PGCE and this video sums up my feeling quite nicely about levelling pupils. When my tutor came to visit me on my first placement to ask about the pupils and if i knew all the data etc i was honest and told her that i hadn't looked at it once. i got to know the class, found out what they could do and what they werent yet ready for and planned lessons accordingly. that is why when most of these kids were targeted L1/2 in french at the time, i was getting them to grasp L4 ideas. Part of me wants to be rebellious and unprofessional to an extent and not focus so heavily on levels/assessment etc, but i do understand why there is that element to it. The day i feel there is too much focus on it that it heavily impacts onthe whole reason for me wanting to teach, is the day that i leave the profession

snippet.textOriginal: There is no difference in saying that a child moves through levels of knowledge/skills or year groups of knowledge/skills. The new assessment arrangements will mean that a child is told at the end of year 6 that they have passed or failed in reaching the expected knowledge at the end of year 6.  So the threshold criticism of levels is irrelevant as implies in spades to NC14 assessment.  Schools will be expected by OfSTED to ensure that all children make as much progress as possible.  This notion of children reaching the end of a year group's knowledge and then deepening their knowledge, rather than moving to the next stage in their learning, does not fit with the accountability system which puts huge pressure on schools to show progress.  How do you measure deepening knowledge?  Oates talks about APP (assessing pupil progress by the way not assessing pupils performance!!!!) as being a best fit system and that children who achieved a level only understood some aspects of it.  As a teacher who has used APP for 8 years, this ignores the rigour and subtlety of APP.  Oates talks about a new assessment system to replace the level system, but the reality is that the new assessment system is a vacuum.  Schools simply do not know what to do.  Most schools are holding onto levels for the time being until a coherent replacement system for assessing children's attainment in NC2014 arises -at the moment there is nothing that has the rigour and accuracy of APP available.  Many schools who have a new system are just changing terminology - levels being called bands or stages.  Bands and stages are then calibrated to old levels so that staff can understand them.  With all schools having the "freedom" to choose their own assessment system for NC2014, how will teachers be able to understand the next steps for children who move into their school? How will teachers from different schools be able to share information about their pupils and compare progress and attainment?  How will OfSTED be able to make valid judgements about different schools locally and nationally? All of the head teachers I have spoken to in my area of Dorset where I have been a deputy head for 11 years cannot understand the movement from a level based curriculum.  All of the arguments given in the video for removing levels apply to the system that is replacing it, (except that levels aren't used in "high performing education systems" - how do you define a "high performing education system?")  There is a deep sense of resentment and anger within the profession about an idealogical change that has caused enormous uncertainty to teachers already under enormous pressure to achieve the impossible.  If it works don't fix it.  Finally 1995, roughly 45% of children achieved level 4 in KS2 SATs, by 2008 roughly 85% of children achieving level 4 in KS2 SATs.  This includes data from a large number of children with SEN who are included in our mainstream schools who would be excluded for other international studies.  If that isn't high performance, then what is?

snippet.textOriginal: With twenty years teaching experience in D and T, I think more open-ended teaching is the direction to aim if D and T is to continue as a subject and grow in schools. Over-prescribed projects - where the brief and spec lock students into a "follow-the-teacher" approach (with only token opportunities for design), really do work against the spirit of the subject and in my opinion continue to hold it back. Having said that, it would be unwise to go unprepared into a class and simply say "write your own brief" without anticipating what would follow. However, if structures and teaching systems have been setup to manage/guide the possible outcomes, you can still get across your "skills" but also develop far greater motivation in your students by allowing these learner-led projects. It takes a bold step to allow this to happen in your class and might seem inappropriate with learners you believe will not cope, but from experience the results can be surprising and extremely rewarding.

snippet.textOriginal: Pupils do not need to be forced to learn things at an even earlier age than they already are.  Growing up and moving from primary to secondary is a difficult enough time as it is! We need to spend more time focusing on giving kids cultural awareness, social skills and the ability to think creatively off their own accord . We're living in a world where 'teaching' has simply become a means of obtaining a grade (through memorizing) that essentially amounts to nothing. The focus needs to be emphasized more towards educating kids to become well-rounded human beings, the rest will fall into place itself.

snippet.textOriginal:
I get the poetry and debate in English, but spelling and grammar bear no relation to 'raising our game' as a country, they are technicalities. All that matters is that people can understand what you write.
Poetry is useful because it is certainly within the creative side of English reading and writing and can stimulate the various associated brain parts, while being sufficiently concise to fit within a single lesson. You can easily read and write multiple poems over a term. Also it teaches attention to detail, as unlike in a  story with 10,000's of words, a poem is so short that each word has to count and be a part of the experience of reading it. In stories words like 'said' and so on are just technicalities.
Debate is about participation, original thinking, critical thinking, and divergent thinking. Specifically about divergent thinking as it is a less familiar term for most, it is the ability to not think in terms of opposites e.g. good and evil, wrong and right, stupid and clever; but of many different things. Debates allow an issue to be thought about in many different ways, and most classes do not divide themselves into two broadly opposing groups.

snippet.textOriginal:
A good short film that highlights the intention of properly challenging all children, particularly those with the potential to achieve more at a younger age.

We may not use a base 12 currency system anymore, "rhythm" may be difficult to spell using phonics and we programme computers through visual interfaces. But knowledge of these things forms part of our culture and should cross generations to act as a foundation for a broad and balanced school led curriculum.

The schools visited Epping Ongar Railway, the closest heritage railway to the capital, and the national "Heritage Railway of the Year".
Epping Ongar Railway is open EVERY weekend and more frequently during the summer holidays, is easy to get to with inclusive vintage buses from Epping Underground Station (Central Line). With steam and diesel trains going through rolling countryside and Epping Forest, it makes an ideal day out for all the family as well as school visits.  @eorailway 01277 365200

snippet.textOriginal: First we have to prioritise the purposes of education. If you define the purpose of education to optimise performance in written exams any evidence based research is likely to come down in favour of learning the things that can be easily measured in those exams and indeed practising the exams. How do we weight the importance of exams against other aspects such as being cooperative, providing leadership, being able to study autonomously etc etc?

snippet.textOriginal: So why is Gove completely changing the education system. Current results in GCSE and A levels are improving over the years, overhauling the system to create a more 'rigorous' system has very little (if none) evidence. In our schools we need to inspire creativity and let intelligence thrive rather than put more stress on students through rigour. There are alternatives to the current system and the (victorian-esqu) proposed system, just look more closely. I am a current student.

snippet.textOriginal: Although I do agree that well-qualified teachers may help produce better outcomes for children, raising classroom ratios will not be beneficial for all involved. As an early years practitioner, I know young children do better in groups with smaller ratios. The teacher can better focus on each child's needs, safety, health and well-being. I grew up in a country where ratios were very high. I struggled in preschool because the teacher could not focus on all my needs. I fear for the future...

snippet.textOriginal:
The UK Phonics Check has already been identified and criticised by numerous academics and literacy experts in the UK and Australia for having a flawed testing methodology. It does not test for phonemic awareness and risks red-flagging the wrong children while overlooking those who may benefit from early intervention.

1) There are children in this video who demonstrate good phonic knowledge who are marked ‘incorrect’.

2) There are children who incorrectly synthesise real words but upon providing the correct pronunciation are marked ‘correct'.

3) There are children who provide perfectly plausible phonic pronunciations for pseudo-words who are marked ‘incorrect’.

snippet.textOriginal: My observation is that linguistic confusion about phonics is not uncommon even amongst 'phonics experts'. The first nonsense word the child is asked to say, 'yed', does not occur with the ‘e’ grapheme pronounced as the phoneme /e/ anywhere in English! It only occurs word finally in words such as eyed and played.  There is one minor exception in the compound word copyedit but that doesn't really count. The principle of testing phonic decoding using nonsense words is not wholly wrong (if that is all one is trying to test) but the pseudo words should at least occur within the phonology of the language. http://www.wordfind.com/contains/yed/
snippet.textDisplay: My observation is that linguistic confusion about phonics is not uncommon even amongst 'phonics experts'. The first nonsense word the child is asked to say, 'yed', does not occur with the ‘e’ grapheme pronounced as the phoneme /e/ anywhere in English! It only occurs word finally in words such as eyed and played.  There is one minor exception in the compound word copyedit but that doesn't really count. The principle of testing phonic decoding using nonsense words is not wholly wrong (if that is all one is trying to test) but the pseudo words should at least occur within the phonology of the language. http://www.wordfind.com/contains/yed/

What Kavafy has stated below is correct. A life skill of decoding ANY word, familiar or unfamiliar, is what the point is. We mustn't decide some word makes sense or doesn't based on our adult vocabulary familiarity. To a 5-6 yr old apparently simple words could very well be nonsense. 
Once the skill is clearly established, sky is the limit for reading!

snippet.textOriginal:
Gove never gives an improvised speech for education, but loves to read from various spin doctored think tanks with a hidden multinational agenda. He has to read because he doesn't have a clue, and wouldn't last a second teaching a class in a state school...

Like his predecessors he is also especially lost when it comes to ICT or computer science. He went to the US and took a lot from Apple's innovations and then pushes open source. A contradiction. He then states that schools need specialist technologies, but yet cuts funding on a major scale. Major Contradiction #2. He states they already know, then why change the curriculum? Contradiction #3. He slated British teaching of ICT after his travels in the US, who themselves poorly teach computer science and their curriculums are massively inconsistent and a key stage or more behind. Contradiction #4 Zuckerberg didn't learn computing at school either, it was self taught and he is from a higher socio economic background and thus the schools and colleges and his upbringing played a major role in his Latin, Greek and Sciences learning. Which also isn't taught across main stream US. Contradiction #5. Zuckerberg as an example is like using a natural skilled Musical artist like Beethoven and then trying to recreate his abilities amongst every child. Flawed in concept #6. Furthermore he slates the British computer science developments, yet much of the computing innovations came from Britain since WW2. A MAJOR BRITISH INNOVATION is the original  internet code by Tim Berners Lee I.e. also naturally gifted who was taught in Oxford England. Having said that once again he was from a privileged background like Zuckerberg which allowed hin to be 1, given an opportunity in one of the best universities and 2, his innovations to be noticed and funded, supported by multi nationals, namely the US defence who built the first inter networked communications for defence purposes.

I understand and fully agree that computer science is paramount across the key stages and welcome it's implementation, however using examples from entrepreneurs who are from privileged backgrounds, naturally gifted and propped up by commercially and govt backed industry is a flawed concept for mainstream British state education. Facebook also developed for the MI6 and British defence industry. It's all about supporting govt backed and multinational agendas, which is by and large the same.

He should have used examples from startups such as the Designer for the IPod who was British and not from a privileged background. But this wasn't about using such examples... It was all about increasingly pushing the commercialised agendas of US and UK multi nationals into schools and making it almost compulsory for academies to be seen as the generic lead in future ICT curriculum. He states the devolvement of state monopoly of curriculum in favour of local level school centred initiatives, yet replaces the state in favour of multinational and business agendas which contradicts his very premise he hypocritically hypothesises.

Don't get me wrong computer science is important, but the reasons and over emphasis on multinational govt backed commercial agendas is viewable for all to see. Once again Academies is also thrown in to push the privatisation agenda further into schools.

This is about ensuring such agendas to be cemented into state schools and INTO THE MINDSETS OF THE NEXT GENERATION, which furthers the commercialised interests of giants like APPLE and GOOGLE. Yet the private schools he was taught within still remain ever independent from such emphasis. MASSIVE CONTRADICTION.

Computer science is important for the beneficience of all, not just to serve commercial interests. If he added that I would believe his self or more precisely commercially prophecised curriculum.

He has also made massive redundancies almost compulsory across every school with already deflated buduets, and the first ones hit were ICT, due to this change, meaning a whole key stage or two have non specialists and many pupils have not been entered for a formal ICT qualification.

By the way I'm an experienced ICT and computing teacher for Key stage 3, 4 and 5 with a 1st in computer science. I welcome Computer science but will never adhere to the commercialised agendas.

snippet.textOriginal:
@samnbrad1 is completely correct, makes the current govt.'s cessation of the BSF programme massively disappointing.

@connectEducator - you seem to be arguing for and against free schools in the same breath. Ultimately, the gamble will result in massive retrospective investment by future generations when we rediscover our responsibility to education.
snippet.textDisplay:
@samnbrad1 is completely correct, makes the current govt.'s cessation of the BSF programme massively disappointing.

@connectEducator - you seem to be arguing for and against free schools in the same breath. Ultimately, the gamble will result in massive retrospective investment by future generations when we rediscover our responsibility to education.

snippet.textOriginal: @erelpc you appear to be equating education to the production of goods. Unfortunately, our children are not commodites that can be traded to the highest bidder. We have a corporate responsibility to educate our children in order to provide for a better society - for all, not just Gove and his millionaire cronies.
snippet.textDisplay: @erelpc you appear to be equating education to the production of goods. Unfortunately, our children are not commodites that can be traded to the highest bidder. We have a corporate responsibility to educate our children in order to provide for a better society - for all, not just Gove and his millionaire cronies.

snippet.textOriginal: @samnbrad1 Completely disagree. We need a fully privately run system, that's regulated by the free market. The government is terrible at regulating things. These plans by the government are also flawed.
snippet.textDisplay: @samnbrad1 Completely disagree. We need a fully privately run system, that's regulated by the free market. The government is terrible at regulating things. These plans by the government are also flawed.

snippet.textOriginal: The start of the end of our state primary education system. Very, very, sad. Heads will have control and 'latitude' - and be accountable to whom, I'd like to know. Each year will bring a different set of parents, so the only continuity will be provided by the'sponsors' - what do THEY know about education and, as they are not direct beneficiaries of the school's services,  their reasons for getting involved are Highly suspect
snippet.textDisplay: The start of the end of our state primary education system. Very, very, sad. Heads will have control and 'latitude' - and be accountable to whom, I'd like to know.
